Interesting project.  A couple of points.  Wood can be classified as hard wood or soft wood.  Balsa is technically a hard wood because of its “closed” cell structure.  Not intuitive because balsa is very light weight.  You should get a different result with a softwood.  Try using a paste type mold release, keep it thin.  The glass squares should be slightly offset to allow a small twist.
BTW Chlorine Dioxide can be found in camping shops to disinfect water.

ok, i thought about this for over a year, and i think ive come up with the best method when it comes to transparency.
in short - you do everything the same up until submerging the wood in mma. first you pour mma, then you carefully put the wood, put a bit more mma over the wood to submerge it completely. afterwards, this is really important, get tweezers, take the wood out and toss it in the corner. the rest continues as on the video.
at the end youll get pretty interesting product that has very high level of transparency.

I would guess that the reason why the paper said to wrap the glass in aluminium foil, is because you're supposed to use to much acrylic that it's likely to ooze out of the edges. This might then also ensure that there is enough acrylic there for the top side to also be smooth. So next time, maybe try to let the bottom glass be a container with edges, but with a perfectly flat bottom. That way you can soak it in acrylic, and make sure the top side to also have enough acrylic.

he production of methamphetamine — and the desire to consume it — is seemingly unstoppable. When precursor chemicals are brought under tight control in one country, like the United States, production simply moves to another country, such as Mexico. When Mexican authorities clamp down, it moves farther south, or into Europe or Asia. Then, the finished product is shipped right back into the very countries that have waged such a battle to eradicate it in the first place.

Most meth smuggled into the United States is made in large labs — "superlabs" — in Mexico. There are many small meth labs in operation in the United States, but these mostly serve to feed the habits of the amateur cooks themselves.

The production of methamphetamine has been made more difficult by federal regulations, like the Combat Methamphetamine Act of 2005, aimed at controlling the flow of precursor chemicals such as ephedrine and pseudoephedrine (found in some cold remedies), as well as other necessary components. Through theft, subterfuge, forgeries, personal connections and sheer willpower, determined cooks are able to collect enough materials to make some home-grown meth.

Being determined and being safe are two different things — almost 6 pounds (2.7 kilograms) of toxic material is produced for each pound of meth cooked. This fact, however, doesn't stop crystal meth addicts from brewing sloppy batches of fuming, stinking, toxic speed in poorly ventilated environments. Houses used as meth labs are often uninhabitable afterward, and cities and states involved in meth lab busts often don't bother with seizing the property, since nobody in their right mind would purchase it at an auction, even at a steep discount. Small meth labs can be found in suburban houses, motel rooms, car trunks, in campsites or in the woods. Outdoor operations often result in water contamination and a dying-off of nearby vegetation [source: Snell].

Large-scale labs are often located inside abandoned barns or warehouses set up specifically for the purpose of factory-line production of methamphetamine. They aren't necessarily dilapidated properties. They may actually be glistening corporate-style factories that crank out countless pounds of meth per year [source: Matthews].

Much as a destination can be reached by taking one of several different routes, so too can crystal methamphetamine be produced by a number of different methods, including scary "shake-and-bake" and "one-pot" processes. All of them, though, involve ephedrine or pseudoephedrine. The entire process can involve as many as 32 different chemicals, but the formula varies by the ingenuity and intelligence of the "chemists" [source: Snell].

Without getting into an exact recipe, we'll look at how large-scale operations (which are more likely to use a methodical and exact approach to their production) make crystal meth.

If the ephedrine or pseudoephedrine isn't already in pure powder form, then it must be separated from the tablets of cold medicine that contain it. To do this, the cold medicine tablets are mixed with a solvent and the solution is then filtered and exposed to low temperatures to separate and remove the inert material of the tablet.
The pure pseudoephedrine is then mixed with red phosphorus and hydriodic acid.
The red phosphorus is then filtered out (and later reused), and the remaining acid is neutralized by adding a lye solution.
A substance is added that will bind to the meth, and the liquid meth is then drained out.
Hydrogen chloride gas is bubbled through the liquid meth, making it a crystalline hydrochloride salt.
This is poured through a filter cloth, and the meth that is left on the filter is then dried.
Once dry, the meth is "stepped on" (mixed down with inert filler in order to maximize profits), weighed and packaged for shipment or sale.
This process generally takes about two days' time and can result in hundreds of thousands of methamphetamine doses.

Try having rubber around the wood with a bit of a gap to prevent the methacrylate from oozing out (account for compression and probably use a smaller weight). Have that rubber slightly thicker than the wood, and use something between the panes to hold the wood down (but not flush to the bottom). The idea being that you would force the wood to be sandwiched and surrounded in the plastic. To hold the wood down maybe a piece of metal with an offset piece of metal welded on (which would pin the wood), and a couple wings on the bottom piece to spring down on it (holding it in place). So I really think your final effort was pretty darn good. But I was sort of cringing at certain parts of your trouble shooting as some of what you discovered empirically is so well known to electron microscopists, lol. We work with so many types of resins including different types of methacrylates. There are certain types of plastic that don't stick to methactylates. Also, when it comes to plant materials, it takes days to go through each step because of the cell walls. I embedded so many plant materials for so long. They are difficult. Real quick, you might want to try starting your embedding with a 2:1 drying reagent to UNpolymerized resin, then 1:1, then 100% unpolymerized resin, each step for a full day. Then do several more days (fresh change each day) with pre polymerized resin with your vacuum. After a few days put it in the oven. Good luck! It's fun to watch 😃.

This is late, but the reason the papers made the wood thin, was to minimize impurity. If you look at the pieces of the 1st video, there are wavy brown lines. They appear because the grain of the wood never perfectly matches the cut of the board. Making it thinner, aka 1mm, which is the thickness of the individual sheets that plywood is made of, you get a near perfect straight grained piece. If you imagine the wood as a collection of individual straws in parallel, the reason for both impurities and why a large scale experiment wouldn't work becomes apparent.

I have a thought about how it might be possible to get less bubbles in the plastic when you add it to the wood. You're basically trying to fill the xylem channels in the wood with the plastic. Well, those channels function in the plant to suck water up from the soil. So my thought was that perhaps they would be more likely to fill evenly if you stuck one end in the plastic and applied suction to the other end and obviously put the piece of wood so that the grain is vertical. I don't know how feasible this actually is but this is basically the mechanism by which plants suck water up to their tops. Photosynthesis releases water vapors out the stoma (plant leaf pores) and this evaporation of water at the top creates a suction force that draws water up from the bottom and it flows through the xylem that you're trying to fill with plastic. Granted that plastic isn't water, this would be how the plant would get stuff to flow through these very same channels. Then I would also submerge the wood in the plastic too but it just seems like the vital part is avoiding bubbles in the central parts of the wood. I wish I could try this but I could probably only realistically come up with the piece of wood.

It is an interesting science experiment... but I don't see how it is a practical replacement for glass or how it is "transparent wood". You remove most of what made it wood, through a long and complex process, and substitute that material with either plastic or epoxy to end up with a still slightly hazy look. So there is very little "wood" left in there, you would have a better material if you just poured acrylic or epoxy into a form with no additives.

There is also the issue that the idea of trying to reduce the usage of glass seems counterproductive, glass is basically 100% recyclable and is something we've been doing since ancient times, just heat it to the right temperature and reshape as necessary. A wood-plastic composite not only takes a lot of energy to make, but it then will take even more energy to separate out before you can recycle the individual elements.

To make full size windows you should use a benchtop planer on both sides of thicker stock than your final thickness. Alternate which side of the stock faces the cutters until you get close to your final thickness. Finish it on a bench sander to final thickness. This will get you much closer to a truly flat surface both sides that are almost perfectly parallel to eachother. Might have to find a local carpenter type like a cabinet maker that would have that equipment. Many communities have community woodshops that have this type of stuff that you can use if you buy like a one day use ticket type thing

Someone may already have suggested this, but a way to stop spreadage of the MMA would be to put a ring of plasticine on the glass slightly larger than the piece of wood. This would seal the liquid in and prevent it from dropping away from the top corners of the wood. A more thorough way - which would also account for shrinkage - would be to drill a hole through the top glass in the margin between wood and plasticine, and put a small square reservoir of MMA on the top. This reservoir would feed in a little extra MMA as the pressure dropped, before it stopped being liquid enough to drain away.

I'm not sure that I'd still consider the end product to still be classified as "wood". I couldn't sit through the entire clip while you describe everything you did in detail, but it seems as though you were submerging balsa wood into a solution that looked like a resin which then hardened. After which, you then went through a gradual sanding and polishing process.. I'm not certain and I really don't care all that much, but as you did that step, it's possible that you completely sanded the softened balsa wood fibers from the resin and the end product is possibly a polished clear resin panel that you imprinted with the grains from the wood before soaking, hardening with the solution and then sanding all but the imprint which was then polished. I expected you to display some evidence of it having wood-like properties and a better reason for wanting to create it than to use as an alternative to opaque glass window panes.. I imagine that you are aware of perspex, that's much more transparent, less labour intensive and I'm almost sure that they could can etch some woodgrain like textures into it if that is a feature you wish to retain. If not, why not leave the balsa wood out of the process and just make your resin solution window panes? I feel that labelling this video as "How to.. ..transparent wood" was a little misleading, I barely consider balsa wood to be wood. It's kinda like the (formerly referred planet) orbital mass or dwarf planet Pluto. That's Balsa 'wood' (like yet not so much). lol As for your expensive workshop... I would doubt that you know what work actually is. You claimed to have been "doing some building" but I guarantee you, what you did was employ workers to do some building. Generally, we do more practical and useful things than  waste (quite a bit of, I expect) time developing a product that appears to be slightly questionable, of no use to anyone and deemed to be somewhat of a success. Anyway, we receive financial compensation for the work we do, since it is needed and of practical use to others, we can then use the finances to employ people to do some building for us, I am seriously shocked if people actually pay for you to make videos. With all due respect, I don't think I'd even hire you as an apprentice or trade assistant. But, if this gig is bringing in the cheddar, best of luck to you, I don't feel that you deserve a cent for this one IMHO. No disrespect intended, just giving you critical feedback.

A couple of suggestions if you ever revisit this experiment. There are relatively inexpensive wood moisture meters used by luthiers and other woodworkers if you wanted to remove that variable.

Another point this one from resin dice casting is that pressure pots seem to be much better at managing air bubbles than vacuum champers can achieve. Especially when using thick polymers that don't flow easily, a pressure pot would both compress any remaining air bubbles and force the MMA into the pores and fibers of the wood. At least when it comes to dice making, visually, the surface finish looks much better than using vacuum alone. You also don't lose MMA to bubbles risking areas where the wood isn't fully saturated.

Best of luck and keep up the good work!

NileRed you seem to be a very intelligent guy. That being said I want to ask you if you know the alleged story of what Thomas Edison said when he was asked about failing to make a more commercially viable light bulb? I will remind you just in case. As the story goes our dear Thomas stated: "I have not failed 700 times. I have not failed once. I have succeeded in proving that those 700 ways will not work. When I have eliminated the ways that will not work, I will find the way that will work."

You never failed my friend. From what I saw every run you made you learned something. You picked up a little tweek or torque that could be done to better your results. Now, I'm nowhere near a scientist I'm a crafter a DIYer, and a female descendant from a long line of carpenters. I don't know all the science/smart people stuff but I can tell you that when using natural materials such as wood you are going to get very, very, uneven amounts of the elements that make up that said material. I'm referring to the lignin mainly.

Different types of wood grown in different parts of the world and then processed in another are going to retain different amounts of their natural elements. On top of that trees and plants grown in more humid areas will have lignin that, I'm going to assume based on my experience building furniture and bleaching wood for various craft projects, will be easier to break down whereas the lignin in those same types of trees and plants in more dry areas may be harder to remove from the wood. The only way to even come close to uniformity in this situation would be to use wood from the same tree. Where you would cut directly from a live or dead dried tree. That would all depend on what you need for what you are doing. In your situation here I would try a rehydrated dried wood. Rehydrating the wood will soften the fibers as you know. I feel like you may be able to remove the lignin a bit easier this way. But then you run into the issue of the water with other chemicals in use...

Whatever you do, don't stop doing all the neat things you do. I wish I had the extra money to support you. Because this kind of content is way better than 83% of what is out there these days, and, a bigger reason, you got my then 14/15 year old, now 17 year old interested in science. To the point, he went from failing to A's and picked up more science and math-based classes. Thank you for that. He was on his way to nowhere fast. He had lost all passion and gumption to do well or even care the slightest bit about finishing school. He had dropped out of all of his sports and had all but given up. Now he thinks he can cure Covid and I hope he does. And this is all thanks to you and other YouTubers like you. But mainly you. Thank you again. The lives you touch will know no bounds. Smile today knowing that you have a positive effect on this world.

P.s. please excuse any grammar, spelling, and punctuation errors that may be in the above writing/typing. It is the middle of the night and I have a sick, adrenaline-addicted, toddler crawling on my head. Literally on my head. While I am sitting up straight. It is hard enough to get this post out let alone check it before my laptop gets closed or I snatch my glasses off my head in a mad dash to catch this kid before he lands in a belly flop on hardwood flooring from the back of the couch. Or maybe he is standing on the console table behind the couch. Oh well, I have taken up enough of your time. Thanks again.

I have no experience with chemistry but I have an idea.

It seems to me like the top side of the wood, while being pressed between the glass panels, is getting a worse surface than the bottom side because of two reasons. One being that as you mentioned, gravity pulls the liquid down and secondly maybe the wood is absorbing the liquid(?) and since the top side doesn't have a steady supply of liquid like the bottom side does (due to gravity pulling the liquid down) it's running dry and creating small empty pockets which is making the surface uneven.

Maybe a solution to this could be to get rid of the glass panels completely and instead suspend the wood in the liquid while letting it solidify. This way both sides of the wood has endless access to liquid. All you would have to do is to sand off the extra millimeters on the top and bottom and then polish it like you did in the video. And since you sand it anyways it wouldn't really be too much of a hassle to do it like this, just a bit more material to sand off and hopefully you wouldn't need to go through the process twice.

I can't remember what you said that the glass panels did in the video so maybe this is completely wrong but it's just a thought I had.
Anyways, great and interesting video!

I wonder if drying it between two sheets of glass in a vacuum desiccator prior to acrylic impregnation would have worked any better than relying on the solvents to boil off during the vacuum impregnation. I also definitely think that a significantly thinner resin polymer solution is optimal for actually wicking into the wood. People who make resin stabilized wood for their projects typically use something called "cactus juice", which is a brand of thermally polymerizing resin, and is probably quite similar to what you did in this video. I'd love to see you take this project on again with some premade resin mix and a sheet of 1mm maple veneer, as maple is already an incredibly pale wood.

A polymer chemist here. So happy that you did a free radical polymerization here! A few notes when you’re doing a radical polymerization:

1. AIBN needs to be recrystallized first prior to use. Maybe that’s why the polymerization is wildly inconsistent.
2. Free radical polymerization involves instantaneous generation of radicals, which is really easily scavenged by oxygen in air. So, to have a more consistent result, I’d suggest running your polymerization under nitrogen atmosphere.

As a woodworker, I really want to use some of this for projects! =) Can only imagine how much time & expense it'd be to make a piece big/thick enough to use though...

Also, coming from the perspective of someone who's worked with wood & epoxies quite a bit might help explain something else. You mention near the start not knowing why the chemical washes are necessary, but that it's probably to remove the water. If you're correct, that is exactly why the samples are stiffer this time - the more water is in wood, the more flexible it is. You bend wood (to make a fishing net for example) by cutting 1/8" thick strips, then steaming them to infuse water into it. Bend it around your form, clamp in place, and it's back to normal strength & rigidity after it dries. If you turn a bowl out of green wood, it's warped after it dries because the radial shrinkage is much greater than either tangental or lateral shrinkage; also why you have to cut the pith (or center part) out of a log so it doesn't crack... you're actually just allowing the wood to move radially so it doesn't break itself apart. Putting the wood into a vacuum chamber at this point would help draw more of the water out, replacing it with alcohol / acetone as you want.

Have to wonder if there's a way to get one chemical into the wood while it's still very thin viscosity-wise so that it'll absorb much more thoroughly, then introduce something else - whether it's another chemical or UV light - to polymerize it. (I'm thinking of the plastics the dentist uses for fillings... it doesn't solidify until he hits it with a UV light.) You're going to know off the top of your head if this is possible though... I'm just a guy who likes tinkering in his shop & thinking too much about strange stuff. ;-) =)

to get rid of an issue of the top surface, I'd try to:
- on the bottom glass, make narrow frame walls (larger than the wood piece) out of silicone, of the original height of wood, to be pressed to the shrunk height under the weight of the tungsten cube
- drill hole(s) into the top glass at the edge of silicone wall, to allow escaping the excessive methacrylate from the volume between the glasses and silicone walls
- fill the whole "pool" made of silicone when placing the wood piece

I think pre-sanding the piece of wood to an extremely fine surface almost like glass-like touch will help the final product. Also, the polymerization of Methacrylate is affected by the amount of oxygen in the solution. If you vacuum your MMA before you mix it with the initiator and heat you will have a faster and even polymerization, meaning that you will have always the same rate of polymerization in the proportion to the amount of initiator. When vacuuming the wood under the MMA try to keep the wood immersed as the vacuum will create bubbles inside the wood and it will float. Something small but heavy on each of the four corners will keep the piece of wood under the methacrylate during the vacuum.
Hope that helps

I’m a bit late to the party, but hopefully you’ll see this. Woodworkers use Cactus Juice (brand name for a stabilizing resin) for infusing wood under a vacuum. Then you wrap aluminum foil around it to prevent it from dripping too much into your over and pop it in. It’s a ready-made, easy solution for infusing the plastic. And as far as I know, it doesn’t have the yellowing problem of epoxy. The pieces that woodworkers infuse with plastic are much larger in all dimensions and require a longer vacuum time though.
Also, if you get stuff stuck between your glass sheets, don’t pull them apart but instead twist them. Any kind of glue-like substance can resist pulling a lot better than shearing forces and you can apply a ridiculous amount of force due to the levering action (ie the larger the glass pieces, the stronger the force at the glue site). Btw this is the best way to remove stuff you accidentally superglued to your fingers. Also here the glass itself only encounters compression, which it can withstand an enormous amount, instead of shearing forces if you try to pull the pieces apart (shearing forces).
I have no idea what the foil in the paper you followed was for, perhaps a remnant for watching a Cactus Juice stabilization video? But if you’re going to sandwich the wood between glass sheets, the foil really does nothing. I would instead consider using blu tack or play-dough in a somewhat thin strand surrounding the piece. That way, it would stop too much of the resin from escaping while also being pliable enough to give room when you squish the glass plates together and all the resin wants to go somewhere so you end up with a perfect fitting mold.
You could also use small blobs of blu tack/play-dough in all 4 corners to act as spacers which can compress, assuming you’re using something to weigh the glass down.
Also I don’t think you need the vacuum cycle if you’re going to re-resin a piece, since you can’t get it inside the wood anymore. Even if you have bubbles inside the piece, it’s already surrounded by plastic and you can’t get to it.
-Sincerely, a woodworking former physics student :D

I think you are missing an important point! You are not matching the refractive index of wood. Cellulose has a refractive index of 1.46 and epoxy is around 1.56. if you want the wood to disappear, you have to match them better than that. Back in the 60's when we wanted to make a resin that would make fiberglass disappear, we would match the resin and glass as close as we could. Even then we couldn't match the RI on all wavelengths of light. 1.46 : 1.56 is WAY off!

hi Nile, Bravo for this it is very interesting, i think what you did is the following. Imagine the wood as lots and lots of hoses very close together. When you bleached the wood, you took all the stuff that was inside these hoses. It turned from yellow to white. Now because there is lots of air cavity, it became translucent than transparent. (many many dioptre). The resin treatment under vacuum, you infused the plastic through these hoses and filled up the air with a medium that is more consistent. Hence light almost was not changing angles and hence it became more transparent. Basically as you discovered it would be very very hard to make thicker wood as transparent as thinner wood because of the much much more variation in light through the bleached wood.

This is really interesting from a purely academic view, or if someone was looking specifically for the specific wood grain aesthetic effect. But, beyond a Youtube video, it's not worthwhile from every other standpoint. For starters, the chemical fabrication process is too time-consuming, inefficient, volatile,  and tedious well beyond the value of the results which are undependable, inconsistent, and entirely of a cosmetic nature. Aesthetically, if someone really wanted something that looked like this, it would be far easier and even yield better and more controllable results to fake it artistically, attain it via some kind of transfer or stain, or by sealing some other innately similar or prepared material in arcrylic. There is even an alternative that is more authentic and appealing in the form of transparent polished "gemstone" petrified wood. The process of making gemstone petrified wood by polishing and rendering petrified wood transparent is actually easier than this and better in nearly every way in terms of the result. The ONLY way something like this would make sense is for mass production, but for what? The material itself does not retain the strength of wood, it apparently has no longevity, cannot withstand weathering, and the arcrylic material that is used as a component is better all by itself. It is utterly useless for any practical purpose, especially its intended purpose as a replacement for glass. Overall, it's a tremendous waste of materials and time, but it made an interesting Youtube video that is best used as documentation to demonstrate why no one, especially any investors or entrepreneurs, should consider it for any reason.

Idea: See what happens when you use wood with high concentration of lignin and ones with low concentration. My hypothesis would be that the higher lignin concentrated wood would leave bigger/more numerous channels in the wood and be much more transparent, while the lower amounts would be much more textured and likely more difficult to get the alcohol and bubbles out.

Another idea: use a bit thicker wood but drill small micro channels against the grain down into it. In theory, this would allow bubbles and incomplete MMA polymer chains to evacuate easier as there are more paths out, but it may affect the end result.

For all intents and purposes, wood = lignin + cellulose. Therefore, wood - lignin = cellulose. Cellulose + MMA = PMMA-impregnated cellulose. Or by wt %, cellulose-impregnated acrylic. Cellulose has been around for almost 100 years, and has very little use or value, as a stand-alone substance in its most common form, cellulose acetate. It also yellows and cracks readily. In my polymer compounding experience, previous to my woodworking career, I've made lots of different composites.  One that's very familiar to most woodworkers is Trex, a composite made from LDPE ("grocery bags") and wood flour. I guess I really don't understand the intent of this work, other than just messing around in a lab. Acrylic has been used for decades as a glazing material. It's fairly UV stable, and amenable to some UV stabilizers (hindered amines, if memory serves, though I think those reduce clarity). So it's able to be enhanced further for UV stability, if the application allows. The addition of cellulose to MMA adds no benefit to either.  It likely detracts from impact resistance and flex modulus/elongation of the acrylic.  It certainly reduces clarity.  And in this work, the major component is not wood, but acrylic. The idea of transparent wood is ridiculous simply because it eliminates the components that provide wood its physical properties.

I know this might sound weird, but try painting the wood on both sides with a no-wipe gel top coat, like a gel-nail polish top coat.  They self level and will fill in all the micro abrasions that can cloud something meant to be clear and make it very shinny.  I do my nails and a lot and have some on hand all the time.  My friend has a 3D printer and tried to print a clear gelatinous cube for out D&D campaign, and when it didn't come out totally clear I painted it with the gel top coat and it got much much clearer.  It has to be an actual gel top coat though that requires a UV/LED lamp (I suggest the LED they're faster at curing the gel) not one of the nail polishes advertised as "Gel Like".

Hi, I am a french chemist and it is a lot of fun to see your experiments. About transparent wood, MMA most of the time is delivered with polymerization inhibitors, it is may be why you had to increase the amount of AIBN and it does not take the same time to initiate. To avoid this you may proceed whith a distillation of MMA before using it.
An idea for the wood inpregnation (I have no idea if it works) : Use fresh distilled MMA not prepolymerized (bp=101°C vs isopropanol 82.5°C) under vacuum, as the viscosity is low, I imagine it can go deeper in the wood, and then sink it in the PMMA slurry. As it is a radical polymerization who grows, with a piece of chance, in the oven MMA will polymerize as well. thank for you chanel, and good luck ofr your future experiments.

Another thing I was wondering was maybe try sanding the wood before the first step maybe with 320 grit sand paper to help open up the grain more and may help with a more consistent surface after the final step. Quick question about the aluminum foil. Did you use the dull side on the inside? Because the shiny side should be facing inside. The dull side absorbs the heat and the shiny side magnifies the heat. A thought about wrapping the last stage in the oven with foil; if your piece of wood is only a bit smaller than the glass plates (or the glass plates only slightly bigger than the wood) the foil could be used to prevent the acrylic from leaking out and also stop it separating from the top piece of glass by filling the space between the glass plates completely. Admittedly, this would make separating the glass plates harder later, so maybe place some thinner wooden pieces (or something) in the edges that can be easily removed so you have somewhere to put a screwdriver tip. Effectively this would be a "bath" arrangement inside the foil. EDIT, later thought, possibly use the foil tape like double sided tape between the glass plates to make the "bath" so there's more chance of being able to take them apart.

Fast dropping rate: more chains - lower viscosity.
Slow dropping rate: viewer and longer chains and higher viscosity

Second, for the final glass pressing process, I'd build a "well" around the part, using something like plumber's putty, to keep the methyl... trapped and basically "fill" the well to overflowing. Ok, some information guides that I believe would account for variations.
1) The plastic polymer, is effected by ambient humidity, which probably gave you variations in the time before it would initiate the hardening.
2) The wood, wood is extremely porous and most of the bubbles or uneven side is caused because the shrinkage and the wood its self. (I have done a lot of woodworking, including making violins/viola/cello/bass) You should have kept the balsa around 20% thicker, and then the final stages of thinning it should have been scraping it flat, while it was wet then scraping while dry, the alternating between wet and dry cause certain parts to swell and shrink, this allows to make a 'near' flat surface, this (with wet sanding) allows that shiny finish to be done on musical instruments.
3) before you put the acrylic into the wood, heat the wood in the oven, and then immediately get it into the liquid.. this will allow the cooling temperature to draw in the acrylic in the initial stages while you get it plated and put into the oven.

This was fascinating. I had heard of Transparent Wood ⊕ before, but hadn't really paid much attention to the methodology. Both getting the Lignin destroying chemicals & then the Methyl Methacrylate to penetrate the wood fibres seems to be a significant problem. It's possible that if you microwave the wood before first baking it (to dry it out), you may denaturate some of the internal structures, allowing for greater penetration of the acrylic solution during the vacuum stage. I get the idea from a method I'd already heard of, to assiste a polymer (Polyurethane, I think..?) to efficiently penetrate into the surface of a hardwood (Jarrah or Karri) sculpture.

⊕ I suspect that tranparent/translucent wood would be best used by architects as a way to filter light through windowless external walls into structures (much like translucent concrete), while preventing outsiders from looking in to the building.

~ ⊚ ~

If you want a different, somewhat tougher, but still very transparent replacement to a Silicon-based glass, then "Transparent Aluminium" / Aluminium Oxynitride (AlON) may be both interesting - & definitely challenging - enough for you to experiment with.

It's serious fascinating stuff, being both near perfectly transparent (extending into the U/V & Infrared parts of the spectrum) incredibly tough - a ceramic approaching the hardness of diamond.

@NileRed, I have a feeling that a few of the preparation steps for transparent wood needs to be done over a longer period of time with a consistent temperature and humidity.

The process of removing the ligning seem especially crucial during this point of the process and the wood of choice seems to determine the quality of the outcome. I can't help but feel that a wood with more Ligning might be more ideal for the process, but these type of wood tend to be more expensive.

And during the process in the oven, you need something that makes it turn slowly and automatically. To prevent the compound from gravitating toward one side. Basically, attach normal packing tape around all four sides of the glass. Then clamp the glass to an apparatus. A bit like this, https://withlocals-com-res.cloudinary.com/image/upload/w_830,h_467,c_fill,g_auto,q_auto,dpr_1.0,f_auto/e117fa290852efc0a9abceb3ae5ce529 but much simpler. Essentially, you want an apparatus that spins the pane of glass in all axis at a consistent speed during the whole process of cooking. And due the spinning, you might want to cook it for longer since movement tends to lengthen the process of certain procedures. Since the molecules are in movement therefore doesn't want to stay put in the same way.

In a way, I think the key to transparent wood lies in the preparation. Where the process of Lignin is directly effecting the result. And I feel the process needs to be done over a lengthier period of time, albeit it will have diminishing returns at a certain point.

For example, start the process at a cooler temperature, then slowly heat it up to room temperature when the early process is done. Scale the temperature slowly up till the solution hits a 'calm'. At that point, pull it out. As you said, this process may be finicky since you can see the result quite easily at this point. The whiter and more transparent the wood is during this process, the better end quality you will get. Nail this part of the process, and you are set for a larger scale.

Also, just a heads up. When it comes to Apoxsee, 1/2 of what you’re using is considered a Hardner. The ratio of what you using the Hardner and the temperature is your timer. You adjust the ratio of the two to get the time you want it to soak. Therefore if you wanted the product to sit in the solution for 24 hours before becoming hard you would need to sit the ratio of your solution more than 1/2 or less than 1/2 depending on the temperature in the room. Do not leave that product covered because you wanted the hydration process to continue. PS: when your project twist and contort in any manner including looking like a potato chip would mean it’s curing way too fast.

I have found MMS to be an extremely effective bacteria killer. One does not need much to kill a lot of bacteria either. A smart user would not start with more than one drop of the formula (it is "activated" using citric acid or distilled vinegar----I have forgotten the proportions but they are probably available online) diluted in several ounces of water, and would consume it a sip at a time over 15-30 minutes until tolerance is discovered. The first hint of nausea is the warning that tolerance has been reached and a smart user will stop at that point. Dosage can be gradually increased if needed and as a bacterial load is decreased, over hours or days or weeks. Often 5-10 drops daily, diluted, ends up being an effective yet tolerable dose, as long as the user work up to that quantity.
Consuming too much too soon WILL cause nasty nausea, vomiting, possibly diarrhea, and even dehydration, but that is because the dose was MUCH too large. And yes, it does smell like bleach to us, because that is the chlorine compound we are most familiar with. It is sort of like eating too much fruit at a time. Fruit is not inherently dangerous, but overdoing it can cause a belly ache or diarrhea. The big caution is to start very small and increase gradually.
It is claimed MMS will destroy viruses but I have found that to be generally not the case

Running both processes with the same wood specimens would eliminate the wood variable in the experiments - as you know - I feel the Process difference had a lot to do with the softening.

As you can see from this paper: https://core.ac.uk/download/pdf/4719913.pdf (and many more) NaOH (and most other alkali metal hydroxides) soften the cellulose and even begin the breakdown of the cellulose chain into sugars. I would bet that the pH difference from alkaline to acidic between the two processes - the the change from a Hydroxide to an acetate buffer is the key factor in the softening process. I would venture to say that a "softening" step could be down after the Sodium Chlorite and Acetate buffer process - if one desired to change the flexibility of the material. Bleaching wouldn't be needed - so a simple NaOH hot water bath then solvent washes to remove the sugars and salts.

Nice persistence and great outcome! A few thoughts for you. First, hopefully you already know this, but methyl methacrylate is a carcinogen and a sensitizer, so please make sure you are taking the proper precautions. AIBN isn't great either! Next up... Polymerization. So you've got a lot of things going on there with that polymerization, and frankly it's fortunate that you were able to get it so clean. Polymerization is a bit non-intuitive. When you used more initiator, you started creating more chains. That means that the AVERAGE chain length will be shorter once you've consumed all the monomer. This matters because it means that you create a lower molecular polymer, and if you add enough initiator, you might even keep the material from gaining enough molecular weight to polymerize to a solid! Usually, you would want to use very low loadings of initiator to achieve very high molecular weight materials. As a side note, AIBN releases nitrogen when you heat it up, and having excess AIBN around might be creating bubbles in your acrylate.

So why is it that you needed more initiator in the first place? The main reason was air and moisture were acting as radical scavengers. If you sparge your acrylate with nitrogen for 15 minutes, and you keep the reaction under nitrogen as you run it, you should need much less initiator, and you'll have a cleaner reaction overall. I also wonder if a UV initiator might be an interesting way to finish the curing process, but that's a guess.

As far as polishing goes, that NOVUS material is a very nice acrylate polishing system, and I have had pretty good luck with it. However, what I might also recommend is using on of those plastic headlight restoration kits. The polishing part of those kits should get you to a place very similar to the NOVUS. However, the magic is in the final wipe. They include a partially polymerized acrylate in those kits which is designed to be photo sensitive. So after all that polishing, you wipe it down with a super thin layer of the finishing compound, let it melt in for 15 minutes, and then cure it with sunlight or a UV light. You should come out with something extremely clear! If you can get your hands on enough of that liquid UV protector sealant, maybe you could infuse the wood with that instead! Then you would have a photocuring piece of wood, though the viscosity might be a bit high for good penetration.

Your chemistry is good, but I think most of the trouble you had was with your technique.  Rather than trying to "mold" a smooth surface with the pieces of glass, you would have been better off just starting with a thick enough piece that it stayed flat, getting the resin hard with the baking, and then physically bringing it to the desired thickness and an optically smooth surface.  This is what you eventually did with the sandpaper and polishing compounds.  I suspect simply coating the surface with a self-leveling gloss finish (maybe a polyurethane) would have given you the same final result.

hi, I loved your video and your patience to get the result you want . . . I enjoyed it

my friend ad I watched your video and we work in polymer lab, and we have some suggestions to achieve a better reproducible result :
first, try to make your polymer under nitrogen to avoid any inhibition of the initiator, just a bit of bubbling with (Nitrogen, argon, or even CO2) through the stopper with a plunged syringe will help to get repeatable results.

Second, If you want to achieve a certain viscosity of the mixture you’ll have to manipulate the polymer chain length and this can be done by monitoring the amount of initiator you put in the polymerization, the more you have the smaller the polymer chains will be ( it’s not exactly true, but it can be considered as for the first hour of the polymerization reaction)

But the best way in our mind is to do a UV-initiated photopolymerization of the methylmethacrylate, all you need is a photoinitiator and a source of UV, and soaking your piece of wood in the monomer would be much easier and you’ll get much better penetration than trying to get a polymer inside the piece of wood, you can also use a crosslinker but it is not necessary if you plan to heat treat it in the over like you already done

hope it will help and keep doing great work . . . .with love from France

Hey Nile

Not sure if this had been mentioned before, or you already took this into consideration...

The tungsten cube is very, very dense and will take a long time to heat up...

This will cause a temperature gradient through your acryllic cure and a gradient in the shrink process.

It's possible that the bottom and edges cured faster than the top, and as a result, the acryllic shrunk into the wood instead of pulling in the cured material.

I'm sure this could be worked around by putting spacer strips of wood between the glass and tungsten to allow airflow, or some other design from your brilliant mind.

Hey, I was just thinking about how the transparent wood video was my favorite (or at least among my favorites)! So happy to see an update

You missed the best part about the "failed" thicker pieces: the fiber-optic effect. You've got dissimilar materials, one of which has a fiber structure and the other of which is clear and has a high index of refraction. You get where this is going, right? Yep: total internal reflection.

Place the end-grain edge of one of thick squares against print, and you should find that you get basically the same effect as you see in ulexite, the bundled fibers serve as a natural fiber optic image relay (which has caused ulexite, and to a lesser extent selenite and satin spar gypsum, to be known as "television stone").

You want to have some real fun, get a 4 inch square chunk of balsa, a thin-kerf saw, and cut yourself some slabs of end-grain.

Oh, and you've got a vacuum chamber, try a vacuum treatment after you sandwich the pieces between glass.

You might look into alternating pressure with vacuum in your treating process, and again, pay attention to any chemicals that can catalyze the reactions.

In your earlier attempt you most likely used an incorrect ratio of resin to catalyst. Epoxy catalyzes via an exothermic reaction. Heat is generated in proportion to volume, and radiates away in proportion to surface area. Increased temperature accelerates the reaction, so thick castings can "run away". The hotter it gets, the faster the reaction, and the faster the reaction, the hotter it gets. This can result in anything from warped, yellowing epoxy to dramatic shrinkage, fire, and explosion.

To compensate, you back off on the catalyst. Chemical contaminants that alter the catalytic reaction can increase this effect dramatically. (Given a sufficiently large vat of resin, a rather small bit of contamination (improperly cleaned stirring rods or vat, or even atmospheric contaminants) can initiate a runaway reaction.

You've done three things: thick casting, unknown contamination, and adding objects of unknown thermal characteristics to the batch. You're lucky all you got was warped, yellow epoxy.

Adding some of my own experience with plastics and silicone:
- Indeed gravity is a problem combined with shrinkage. If you want a perfect smooth surface, it must not be subject to gravity and pressure. Therefore, placing the plates vertically would be superior.
- You did not vacuum treat the whole assembly with glass, potentially trapping some air inside.
- The activator you used is sensitive to moisture and was not dried, which affected reaction time unpredictably.
- Cold cure PMMA resins have much better dimensional stability and shrinkage, which is important for this use. Cold cure resin can also be polymerized under vacuum for even finer surface. It still gets to be heat treated but after the resin has cured.
- UV cured resins are even better, but more expensive.

I cant speak to the chemical process but as a carpenter i see a possible reason for your trouble with the translucency. The original pieces look to be end cuts from a piece of dimensional lumber. The balsa you used appears to be layered ply and not dimensional lumber.. ply is pressed layers with glue spread between them. 1 the glue might cause problems.. and 2 the transparency effect would seem easier to accomplish looking through or with the grains as opposed to crossing the grains.. think of looking down on a 2x4 that fell on the ground as opposed to looking at it end on like a telescope. The telescope perspective would be looking with the fibers like fiber optics. This would also be very similar in warping because the grains have strength long ways but not so much on a short cross cut.

Looks like it needs to be baked while still ever-so-slightly submerged. A reasonable approach would be to use a glass dish filled with the methacrylate; the wood (pre-treated with methacrylate in the vacuum chamber) is placed in the dish such that it is (again) submerged. A thick (exceeding the height of the surface of the fluid) piece of glass or a steel gauge block [extremely smooth by design] is placed atop the wood and weighted. The whole assembly is put in the oven.

The issue (afaik) is that the methacrylate begins to bleed out at the edges of the wood and is pushed from the grain at the top. This is probably why the edges of the piece are always more diffusely reflective in a woodgrain pattern. Submerging it ought to solve that issue. A bunch of acrylic would have to be cut away in post-processing, though, and one might get cracks where the acrylic shrinks around the glass/gauge block.

So first amazing video and second I am woodwork and have been for 8 years or so, I am a finisher by trade and one of the things that do affect a finish is the density of wood because when staining the density of the wood can affect the coloring of the stain, more dense woods like Maple when stained do not stain as dark nor do they hold the stain as long as other species like Alder. Now when you were talking about porous wood 1 particular species came to mind which was Oak (White and Red) the reason being is because when staining Oak you have to keep an eye on it because it will leak out the stain from the grain and create dark blotches of stain so you have you use an air compressor and blow out the stain from the grain, the main reason I bring up Oak is that it is quite porous due to its grain structure which is basically taking straws and compressing them together and then gluing them and with the experiment you are conducting I do feel that Oak would work quite well. Now Oak is a denser wood compared to Alder but because of how its grain is formed I feel it would be quite helpful within this type of experiment.

@NileRed Did you ever try to do the vaccum process after completely drying the wood? replacing acetone with the methylacrylate sems so wrong bc it adds all these bubbles in the oven when the unavoidable remaining acetone traces expand. Stabilizing wood is a proven practice and it's always done with dry wood, replacing air with resin, not a fluid like acetone. when tiny air traces are heated, they expand a bit, but fluids that go into gas phase make much larger bubbles, larger by several orders. Also, check with the stabilizing professionaly about the best cycle schedule, maybe more and shorter cycles are better than your 3 very long cycles.

Hi there NileRed. My name is Michael and I am a former polymer chemist and materials scientist. I have worked extensively with radically initiated polymers and methyl methacrylate derivatives and oligomers. I have a couple of pointers. The AIBN radical initiator is typically recrystallized before use in experiments by using a minimal amount of room temperature organic solvent like ETOH to dissolve as much AIBN as possible and the mixture is subsequently cooled to -20 C in a freezer for 24 hours. The final pure AIBN crystals are then recovered with vacuum filtration. Next, most monomers like MMA are shipped with an inhibitor. Butylated Hydroxy Toluene (BHT) is a favorite radical inhibitor that is frequently used to prevent things like UV light from initiating uncontrolled radical polymerization of the product prior to intended use. Typically this inhibitor is removed by a process of running the liquid monomer through a basic alumina column, which like many methods of chromatography, selectively allows the monomer to pass while retaining the inhibitor. Lastly, your polymerization method for the MMA is whats known as a "bulk free radical polymerization". The mathematics of these polymerizations are rather complex, and they are, by their nature, rather difficult to control. I am close to positive that the first two suggestions above will make your initial bulk polymerizations more predictable, however if you are looking for a method to control the exact chain length of the pre polymerized MMA I would suggest looking up the so called "controlled" polymerization techniques, of which Reversible Addition Fragmentation Polymerization (RAFT), Nitroxide Mediated Polymerization (NMP), and Atom Transfer Radical Polymerization (ATRP) are the most prominent. I specialized in RAFT and though it is the most dependable of the three it requires anoxic conditions to work well and access to liquid nitrogen for a process known as Freeze-Pump-Thaw. I would suggest looking into ATRP. Supposedly the process is very easy. This is of course, dependent on how far down this rabbet hole you wanted to go. It seems to me that the longer the chain length of initial PMMA the more difficult permeation into the cavities of the wood. The shorter the length the more likely the oligomers are to evaporate during your infusion process in the vacuum tank. Controlled may let you find an optimal length to get the happy medium necessary to overcome the issues you currently face with the final material surface. Good luck!

Wir wollen es uns in einem Modell veranschaulichen: Man stelle sich einen ungewöhnlich großen Ameisenhaufen vor, in dem sich unter den ansonsten schwarzen Ameisen nur eine einzige rote Ameise befindet. Es ist leicht einzusehen: Je größer der betrachtete Haufen wird, desto kleiner ist die Wahrscheinlichkeit, die eine rote Ameise zufällig (z.B. mit verbundenen Augen) herauszugreifen.
Die Frage lautet nun: Bei welcher Ameisenzahl ist die Wahrscheinlichkeit, die eine rote Ameise zufällig herauszugreifen, gerade genau so groß, wie die, dass sich 3268 Prophetien zufällig erfül-len können?
Wir beginnen mit einer Schätzung: Reicht eine Badewanne voller Ameisen aus, oder muss die Wassermenge des Bodensees durch Ameisen ersetzt werden oder ist gar das Volumen einer Erdkugel mit Ameisen zu füllen?
Die Berechnung zeigt: Es sind immer noch zu wenige. Was nun? Was drückt eine solche immense Zahl – also eine Eins, gefolgt von 896 Nullen – von randvoll mit Ameisen gefüllten Universen aus?
Die Wahrscheinlichkeit, dass sich die über 3000 Prophetien zufällig erfüllen konnten, ist somit praktisch Null.
Die Zahlenergebnisse der mathematischen Berechnungen wachsen derart ins Gigantische und Transastronomische, dass unser Denken und Vorstellungsvermögen weit überfordert sind, um diese Realität noch angemessen einzuschätzen. @NileRed not sure if anyone else has mentioned this but the reason you have been having mixed results and varying reaction times with your MMA synthesis is because of two factors: 

1) dissolved oxygen can and will scavenge free radicals. this can be fixed by several freeze-pump-thaw cycles (more effective but more labor intensive) or a purge with nitrogen (easier but less effective. usually still more than effective enough for volumes >5 mL), and 

2) the MEHQ additive in the MMA will also scavenge free radicals. in the lab i usually remove this by a simple chromatography through activated basic aluminum oxide (brockmann I).

Some insight from a woodworker:
The relative success of the balsa wood was likely due to the fact that it is less dense and more open-pored than the basswood of his previous attempt. This makes it easier for fluids to seep into the grain. Not only does this help the resinating process, but it also requires less exposure to the harsh bleaching agent. This is partially why these pieces seemed stronger than the basswood attempt. For this experiment, the sapwood of a lightweight and diffuse, highly-porous hardwood would be best. This is because it is light-colored and has large pores distributed evenly, rather than being concentrated sporadically. And balsa qualifies quite handily.

I do some experiments with wood infusion at home, so wanted to make some comments on this. I have not read the papers that were quoted, but based on reading the internet and trying things at home, you are supposed to wrap the infused wood piece with aluminum foil so that uncured PMMA does not escape during curing. It also helps with release immensely, skipping mold release requirement. There are tons of videos on the net if you search for 'cactus juice' (which is one kind of MMA trade name). You are absolutely right questioning wrapping whole glass piece with foil, as it makes no sense. Assuming that you do sanding post-processing anyways, you can still put the wrapped piece between glass sheets in order to make the piece flat and deal with imperfections post-cure with sanding/polishing. The question that haunts me though is that why would anyone consider this for production purpose if you still need to infuse wood piece with with acrylic or epoxy if you can make 'glass' from pure acrylic to begin with. But it makes a nice video and also makes one think of other potential uses of lignin-free wood.

I would suggest the reason for the poor quality of finish is that as you are probably not a woodworker is that you are not aware of the properties of wood surfaces when processed. To me the error you have made is that you have made no real preparation of the wood itself before starting the clarification process. The way that the balsa is sawn/shear cut to thickness means you have a smooth side and an rough side which has lots of micro fuzzies on it. You should on both sides first wet the surface of the wood with clean water and leave to dry. this will raise the grain of the wood so that you can then sand using a block (not you hand) to get an even surface going from 120 grit up to 400grit. Clean off the surfaces with a Tack rag. then start the clarification process. You will see a dramatic change in the surface quality of the end result.

I can definitely empathise with not wanting to support crappy businesses exploiting the wallets of the under-educated and gullible. I do a bunch of security research on hardware devices, including RF attack surface work and EMI fault injection attacks, and it's almost impossible to buy good quality portable faraday cages (particularly box type cages) from anyone that isn't marketing them as "blocks 5G brain implant waves!" nonsense.

The market's so saturated by them that I almost considered giving in and just buying one, after days of searching, but I always come back to picturing someone who can't really afford to spend that kind of money on on expensive junk, but who has been suckered into thinking that they need to protect their family from the RF bogeyman. I can't ethically reward that kind of exploitation.

Luckily, I recently found a less shady supplier from a digital forensics buddy - their gear costs a little more, and the selection isn't quite as good, but the products are really good quality and I'm far happier not putting cash into the hands of the kind of people who farm conspiracy theorists like a cash cow.

Polymer chemist here, and I have a few suggestions if you want them.
Your polymerization is a tricky one, you want to start it, pause it and revive it. Very difficult with that initiator. Your problems with the first polymerization is almost certainly air. Oxygen reacts with the free radical and kills it. try under nitrogen stream. also a VERY small amount of oxygen scavenger would help. we use 0.002-0.005% wt of monomer of sodium hydrosufite in our water based system. don't know if it will dissolve in MMA. Try purging the vac chamber with N2 or CO2 and break the vac cycles with it.

Mold release is also a pain in the A##. Most is made to spray as mist onto a HOT mold. Never seems to work right on cold surface. Hard to keep small molds hot. Somebody makes a silicone release in diethyl ether that works better at room temp. Gold can, i think from Canada.

We made PE resin bars once that had your top surface problem. In your case prob. N2 from residual initiator. We were successful with using strong spring clamps to press the plates and baking the glass on-edge so all the bubbles formed along the top edge. We then cut that off and had smooth sides. Used a high-temp wax to form a seal on the other 3 sides to hold the liquid resin. Bought as a sheet with adhesive prepared on 1 side abt 1/8" thick.

Might also experiment with pulling the mold apart hot, or at least warmer. poly-MMA turns brittle (tg) about 105°C. As it cools and contracts it might be making micro-fractures pulling away from the glass. Try opening at 80°C and see if it helps. With our PE resin each recipe had a best de-molding temp. Trial and error, heavy on the error!

Good luck! Might have to give this a try if we hit a slow stretch. Great Vid! thanks.

I know this will get lost in the sea of comments, but it seems like one of the biggest issues was the methacrylate seeping down during the baking process. Luckily, this is an issue that has been solved in the cooking world! The solution is to use a rotisserie/ spit roast! By spinning the product slowly, not only does it provide much more even heating, but also the fluids inside stay even throughout the thing that you are heating. Maybe something like this would help when scaling up to a window? Instead of just placing a weight on top, you'd need some sort of clamp, though.

Hey NileRed, in order to improve your process of infusing the wood with resin you are on the right path using a low viscosity solution of resin. However your procedure with the vacuum could be improved upon. What you would need to do is real simple if you have the right materials. I'll try to make this simple. What you need is to create a vacuum bag with a resin inlet and a vacuum outlet to draw the resin into the wood without any air. Seal the wood into your bag and remove all the air with a vacuum pump. Then introduce your low viscosity resin into the system via the resin inlet until you see the resin has diffused over and through the wood. Keep the vacuum running and the system sealed by closing your resin port and use a heater blanket to cure the resin. With some sanding and polishing you should receive a satisfactory result.  Look up videos on Fibre glass infusions to get a better idea. You could even get color added using this method as well with the proper resin solutions. But I don't expect a 3rd transparent wood video.

So a couple of thoughts, ideas...

In the vacuum chamber, why not heat it a bit to counteract the cooling from the vacuum evaporation? Not enough to polymerize it, but to keep it fluid.

The MMA itself, was there any sort of measurement of the target viscosity? Obviously thinner flows better than thick, I'm just wondering if there's a tradeoff between polymerized material and non.. might be chasing a paradox.

In the oven... Putting a 40 pound block of top of the glass might be nice for squishing it, but how long does it take to raise all that thermal mass to target temperature. If they said to cook it for 4 hours, would that 4 hours actually be what you were looking for cook time including the temperature raise time? Is it actually cured?

Ultimate test, instead of using balsa wood in sheet form, why not use wood pulp and make a slurry that can be processed?

The biggest problem with this as a 'glass window replacement' is that you're basically making acrylic panes with cellulose embedded in it.

We already acrylic panes. You make them the same way, except you don't put cellulose in it, and they're optically clear.

As a practical product, this really doesn't have it, but as a beautiful object, hell yes.

Scale it up to full sheets of balsa (to fix your surface finish problems, you probably actually just want to space the wood out from the two halves of the mold so there's a layer of acrylic on either side of it, and then just cut smaller to get around those spacers. So you end up with, say, a 1/8th sheet of acrylic with 1/16th of wood-impregnated-acrylic in the center and a 32nd of acrylic on either side that have a normal surface finish and respond normally to surface treatment and you've got a neat alternative to frosted glass. In future, if you'd like to measure the viscosity and spare yourself the time of trial and error while watching the beaker all the time you could use Ford cup for testing. It's standarized viscosity testing for liquids and gives good ballpark estimation. In an essence what it does is, it tests flow time of a liquid through a standarized funnel. Since, I assume, you wouldn't be interrested in any value according to the standard and it would be just for the purpose of reaching a desired value, you could use one of glass funnels you have. Also, I am wondering, it would be a nice attempt to make the polymerisation in-situ, because as I see it, it all boils down to the problem of viscous MMA penetrating the wood. I don't know why the prepolymerisation would be required here. Penetration of wood with pure MMA with AIBN mixed-in would be much easier and after that the whole polymerisation step would be carried out in the oven. The only issue to deal with, would be to be sure that acrylic stays in the wood instead of sink out of it.

Also, there is a huge variation in time with your free radical polymerization because of something called the "inhibition period." Because these reactions involve free radicals and are terminated by singlet oxygen, any oxygen dissolved in your MMA will terminate your reaction. So until the AIBN scavenges all those oxygens, your reaction will proceed insanely slowly, or not at all. Variations in day to day conditions with oxygen are typical

For the surface finish: You need to add a layer of MMA directly to the glass for the MMA in the wood to interface with. This is how glassy finishes in epoxy is done. You'll need to polish it afterwards, as mold release isn't exactly smooth. You want to be polishing the polymer, not the wood, which the extra layer of polymer on the glass helps achieve. Also, you should put the glass/wood sandwich in the vacuum chamber to pull out the air before curing.

Hey great video! It sure seems like I would lose my patience way before then end result :) I do however have some experience with balsa models as well as car detailing, which I think might come in handy.
First the balsa. It would help to sand it beforehand, but as balsa is very soft you need to not use a lot of force and use fine grit paper. Also when removing the pieces from the glass I would make sure to bend it against the grain as it is stronger in that direction.
Last the polishing. What you did is pretty good, but you should make sure that you focus on what part of the piece you polish so that it is polished evenly. Also adding car wax after all the polishing will fill the minor imperfections and remove the light refraction, making it more clear. Let the wax sit until nearly dry before wiping it off, but not completely. I would try with a fluid wax first and if that doesn't make it close to perfect maybe a bit harder one. If you want to make that last (as wax only lasts for so long), use a bit of car paint sealer.

Hey Nile, I have some tips for you about the polymerisation reactions. You should be aware that oxygen acts as an inhibitor and will capture radicals from the AIBN or growing polymer chains. If you want more consistent results try bubbling an inert gas, I use nitrogen, through the liquid beforehand to displace the oxygen and seal the flask. About the viscosity, two things cause it to increase, making more polymer and longer polymer chains. To make polymer, simply let the reaction run longer. For longer chains, it's a little counterintuitive but adding more initiator actually decreases the length of the chains and will result in a low viscosity. One last tip, AIBN should be recrystalised from methanol before use as it soaks up water over time and you weight out less than you think.

I would like to see you try 3D printer photopolymer resin. One can adjust how runny it is with heat and it's polymerezations is faster. Minutes with proper UV light, instead of hours in oven. You can smooth it with more resin and UV light or just some lacker. I use it to make clear parts (i.e. headlight glasses and windows for models). Even if the part is not clear when printed, I spray them with self levelling polyurethane lacker and they become crystal clear. Minimal to no sanding/leveling required. The lacker also protects the parts from UV, so they don't turn yellow over time.

This is pretty cool and all, but I don't quite understand the benefit of 'transparent wood'.
Since every kind that has been made so far ends up being much weaker and more fragile than the starting wood, they all involve impregnating the wood with a plastic. Your transaprent wood video is one of my favorites, so I was very happy to see that you have tried again.
One of the problems you had the first time is that you did not dehydrate the wood enough before adding the resin, so it was brittle and broke easily. The Distilled Water> Ethanol> Acetone steps are crucial and I'm glad you did it this time. It is a very common technique in microscopy.
When you prepare biological samples of tissues, be they animal or plant, you have to cut them very thin so that they can be used under the microscope. Now, the cells are very fragile and very thin cuts cannot be made. For this reason, what is done is to replace all the water in the cells (which can be up to 80%) with a more resistant material: paraffin (optical) or resin (electronic). Actually what you are doing is exactly this same process, only in larger sizes, and you have already seen that with those previous steps to dehydrate they have improved the process a lot.
In general, if you accept the advice of a biologist, plant cells are very little porous and it takes a lot to get any material inside, so if you want to make thicker pieces of wood you have to leave it much longer to remove the lignin, because it is very difficult for the solution to penetrate inside. Also for polymerization, we normally use cubic molds where we put a little resin already polymerized in the bottom, and then the sample, so that the surface of the same is not irregular. From the final cube we cut sheets of a few microns, but it is much easier if you also want to make millimeters.

things i noticed that will help you if you revisit this to scale it up and will give you a higher quality product.

when you pull the vacuum to bring the resin into the wood, skip the ice bath and go straight to the vacuum pump. the cold created during the vacuum process will cool it and the decreased initial viscosity will let it penetrate the wood faster and deeper.
don't use the tungsten cube. it is messing with your heat distribution in the oven. the tungsten cube is slow to heat which means the top of the wood is being cooled by it and wont polymerize at the same speed as the bottom and that's why it isn't coming out right. also, without the bracing, which was unnecessary, the tungsten cube is pushing resin out of the wood.
polished stainless steel will work instead of glass. it has to be polished with jewelers rouge or it will leave marks in the wood, but it wont break like glass. you may have to adjust your cooking time a little longer, or preheat the plate steel.
for bigger and thicker pieces, try roughing the large flat sides with low-grit sandpaper so the resin can get inside faster and easier. the resin will fill the rough edges when it cures.
don't put the tape on the edges with tension, it will bend the glass slightly and pinch the edges of the wood and force the resin out like the cube does, and it also could trap bubbles in the center of the wood piece during the drying process.

Truly making wood transparent is entirely in the bleaching treating process. First, using sawdust you continually react solvents with the wood to clean it up until it's clear. Once you have a working method, you test the solvents step by step on a piece of wood to see if the wood maintains its structure (and strength). When you're done making it clear you dry it and then polish it. That's the only way to truly make clear wood. There is no other way.

Thoughts:
1) Properties like shape and thickness will affect both volume and exposed surface area thus affect both evaporation (or any gas removal) + heating/cooling (any heat transfer). You might need to adjust each process to account for the changed ratio of [exposed surface area] (the bottlenecks for transferring heat/gas) to [volume/mass] (the amount of heat/gas that's being transferred), all over [whatever time interval these properties need to be changed to their desired levels] to reach each intermediate stage.
2) Tungsten has 43% the thermal conductivity of copper and is also a giant thermal mass/heat reservoir. Depending how much heat is leaving your sample, the cubes will throw off whatever the expected heat transfer is in/out of the sample while in the oven for the top side, even if the tungsten is brought to the same initial temperature as that of the initial oven interior. The plywood boards at the bottom are much more insulating and would slow heat transfer between the sample bottom side and the oven.

You could try something like thermally insulating the tungsten from the glass or putting an equivalent piece of tungsten on the bottom, but perhaps just using clamps on the glass plates would achieve the same with fewer changes to the dynamics of the thermal transfer (unless the paper was also using tungsten cubes an' everything).

Hey, have you ever considered using a porous, naturally wicking wood like red oak in this process?

Maybe balsa is already porous -- I'm not overly familiar with it, but it seems more spongy than straw-like to me -- but Louis Sauzedde has an excellent video demonstration of the porosity of red oak in one of his videos.

I'm not sure how the porousness compares to balsa wood, but the porosity of red oak is favorable in-of-itself while being stronger, as well as being relatively cheap and available here in North America. Bamboo also has a similar straw-like structure while being very strong, and maybe that can work as well or even better for making transparent sheets of wood if you can find some to work with.

I'm wondering if a highly porous hardwood would work better than balsa wood.  Ring porous Red oak, for example, will draw water a couple of vertical inches by capillary action, which can then be blown out the end as the pores are so large, straight and continuous.  This makes red oak a poor choice for boat building as a small breach can cause a large area to become saturated. This is the property that would be good for your experiment as it would make it easier to leech out the lignans and infuse the polymer.  A thicker piece of wood is then likely possible. We call the crazy cracks crazing in the cast acrylic business haha. You can't put a solvent (the raw mma) in something that's been polymerized, it starts to break down and you end up with the micro cracks, aka crazing. Also I think your main issue is you're trying to do the process too quickly. Idk the terms of scale, but we make cast acrylic tubes and rods, they're much larger and much thicker, but a solid 6" 6' rod takes us about 40 days to totally complete its polymerization, then we do a final high temp cure. It's the same process for something smaller but less time. A 1/8" thick tube takes roughly 7-9 days depending on the diameter. The scaling makes zero sense and my company has had 60 years of trial and error to figure out our formulas hahaha.

ClO2 is also used in mouthwash. It is a very effective bactericide. It is used in Germany and Italy for disinfection of water supplies (superior to ClO "bleach" as used in USA, because it oxidizes things by adding oxygen instead of adding chlorine, so it doesn't create chlorinated hydrocarbons). It is FDA-approved for sterilization of food preparation surfaces without a rinse. It is used to disinfect cruise ships between journeys. Remember the Anthrax Crisis where someone sent anthrax-infected letters to members of Congress? As a response to that, all Congressional mail is now disinfected using ClO2. So, to say truthfully "there is no evidence it does anything" you must restrict your definition of "evidence."

"Evidence" in the medical/government world is defined as very expensive tests that nobody will undertake unless there is significant profit potential AND a patent. I don't think this is a very sound way to discern the truth, as it is guaranteed to have blind spots. There will forever be "no evidence" for many many things that are both true and important.

In the vacuum treatment step, you should start with the DRY WOOD.  Put that under vacuum, a good vacuum (0.001 torr) with good 2-stage oil-sealed vacuum pump, not one of those piston pumps that is lucky to reach 20 torr.  Keep it under vacuum until the pump stops laboring (you can hear change in sound).  Use gas ballast during the initial part of the vacuum process, then close the ballast, and let under vacuum for at least an hour.  Mix up the resin, and independently degas it.  Then, WHILE WOOD IS STILL UNDER VACUUM, submerge it under the resin (introduce resin through valve, or use a heat-curing resin that can be processed along with the wood inside the chamber, BUT THE WOOD NOT IMMERSED UNTIL AFTER THE VACUUM TIME (tilt vessel to dump resin onto wood).  You need a resin that has a low vapor pressure, not PMMA!  After it is submerged and all bubbling has stopped, slowly release the vacuum.  Wood must be well under the surface during this step!  You want to apply & remove vacuum ONCE.  In glass sheet setup, have top sheet smaller, and dam around larger sheet so weighted top plate is submerged when you go to oven.  Put Teflon sheets on glass.

The polishing part goes into my wheel house. I would suggest electric buffing means. Doing the buffing with compound by hand is never going to get you amazing results (unless you work on it for days). An electric buffer will allow you to do a much more consistent pressure while buffing, which will yield better results (let alone be faster). The the initial drying process, the reason you need to do that no matter how long the wood has been sitting around is because wood will absorb some moisture in the air as long as there is any. So the only way to keep wood with an MC ("moisture content" this number is a percentage of the total weight made up by water) at 0 is to keep the wood in a zero humidity environment. This is why wood doors can sometimes get tight in the wetter months of the year, they absorbed moisture and expand.

Different woods will absorb different amounts of water and have different densities but generally 4%-10% mc is a number you will find inside air conditioned/heated areas.

The wood grain is an important factor. Since the lines are running across the wood, the solutions have a harder time reaching the center since the “veins” or vascular system of the wood are longer.
