Hi Nile. At the 10 minute mark.
As you know there are Epoxy Resins that are UV Resistant. Those types can be permanently preserved from yellowing with a lacquer of UV Resistant clear gloss.

There are two ways Epoxy yellows, One is that sun degrades it over time but the second that is what you have suffered; the base epoxy must be stored at a consistently lower than average room temperature. Around 12 degrees C works best in my experience. It is spoiled the moment it hits 20 degrees C if it doesn't have the hardener added. That way you won't get the instant yellowing effect from curing that you have suffered.

Some very interesting findings.
Especially the crack formation on the second heating which caused some light polarisation.
A lot of the problems you experienced are all common composite manufacturing issues (i.e. poor release, pin holes on the surface, and not fully saturating the fibres).
It would be very interesting to try this with an approach similar to ‘vacuum-assisted resin transfer moulding’ - often called ‘resin infusion’. You would have to use the MMA in a far less viscous state and draw it through the balsa with using the vacuum. After the part had been fully infused, you could keep the everything under a vacuum as you cure it. Similar to how prepreg composites are cured in an autoclave.
Maybe try ramping the heating up to 70C and then back down again whilst under vacuum to help reduce the heat-induced stresses you seem to have, causing the warping once cooled.
If you were to infuse it with glass on one side and a plastic bag on the other, you could polish the non-mould side to help with the transparency.
Check out the easycomposites YouTube page for some really good composite tutorials.

I think you got pretty incredible result.
If you want to improve penetration of the plastic into the wood, try to figure out how to submerge the wood into the plastic in the vacuum. If you submerge it first, then the plastic is preventing the air to escape from the wood pores, both by its pressure and by its viscosity. If you remove air first, it will escape easily from all wood pores and there will be empty space for the plastic to fill once you release the vacuum. Just one vacuum cycle might be enough then.
My hazy idea how to do it involves putting the wood into the dish dry, and attaching a beaker with the plastic to the lid using a magnet (with one side being fixed so it tips over when the magnet is removed rather than just falling down). Once there's vacuum in the chamber, remove the magnet and the beaker will empty into the dish over the wood.
Another option would be a hole into the side of the chamber with some o-rings for seal and a metal rod going through it to hold the beaker over the wood. Much better for manipulation but also much harder to implement.

I've had the exact same experience with the Methyl-Methacrylate, also from Sigma. I think it has something to do with added additives they use to prolong the storage life of their product and enable them to ship it across the sea.
Distilling the MMA, under vacuum, right before use (actually, keeping the distilled MMA in a freezer that very rarely gets opened, seemed fine and it was still non-viscous and completely usable a couple of months after distillation) was all that I had to do to get the polymerization process working nice and consistently.
Simply adding more free radicals to 'use up' the added stabilizing agent, just never gave good, consistent results.

I know that you really like the wood grain, but you might want to try this again with end grain. The xylem and phloem go up a tree almost like straws. If you instead cut the face of the wood (like cutting a sliver from a tree stump), you will be left with 1.5mm straws instead of 4 inches. This would allow the MMA to penetrate much more easily. As a dental technician, we use MMA in combination with a dust which is PMMA (poly metyl metacrylate) to make prothesis.

The process is very different, because the MMA reacts with PMMA to form the bonds forming plastic. Compared to here, where you are trying to put MMA inside the wooden piece.

The only thing that comes to mind is to have it cure under vacuum, as that is what we do with prothesis. Ideally, we use a separating liquid, and a mold of gypsum inside a brass cuvette (? not sure about the name in english), which then sits under water, heated up and under pressure.

The water presence is to remove any air present, as air tends to combine with the MMA, the heat speeds up the polymerization, and the pressure prevents any bubbles from forming inside the construction.

You might want to look up how prothesis are made, as it may give you some hints on this particular project.

You really need to keep the vacuum on it when it's curing. Try a vacuum bag and pull your fluid through it. Then put the entire bag in the oven when it's ready.

Also try finishing it with an automotive clear coat and polishing if your goal is more clarity. I think you sanded down into the wood and exposed the edges of the wood grains. The correct clear coat should protect an epoxy from the UV that would cause it to yellow.

If you cut the wood so that it was all end grain, like a lice from a 4x4, the process and end result would be much, much better. Using an end grain slice would make the capillary length quite short. It also allows the diners to act as optical fibres, making the transparency effect much more striking. With end grain, laying on a book page makes the text (image) “jump” to the other side of the wood.

I have a few ideas for refining this process, I could just be talking out of my ass, but hear me out:

Maybe instead of starting with a piece of desired thickness, maybe start with the thinnest possible pieces you can that add up to the desired thickness when stacked together. This could perhaps help with the lignin dissolution process as there's more surface area and less penetration required as the pieces are thinner. Then the multiple thin pieces could be layered on top of each other in the acrylic process, perhaps alternating the direction of the wood grain as you stack the pieces, sort of like layering fiberglass. I'd also be interested to see how a pressure pot does in this process as opposed to a vacuum chamber.

So, if one of the product goals is a replacement for glass, how is transparent wood in principle a better alternative to plexiglass? Seems to me that if you have to infuse it with plastic, you may as well just use plastic. Very impressive process and you did a good job with it, I'm just struggling to understand what it's for.

Don't know if you can manage this, but:
- to keep the methacrylate from seaping out of the wood, you can build yourself an enclosure on the glass plate so that the wood effectively swims in a pool
- N2 will generate during polymerization initiation with your initiator, I think you will not get completely gas free with this kind of reaction. One solution would be a pressure pod during polymerization, but in this case you would have to have a heated pressure pod, or put the pressure pot into the oven for 24-48 hours to really heat everything through inside
- you could also try to switch the initiator to a UV-initiator, and buy strong UV-light. This would prevent you from using the weight on top, but there might be UV-initiators that do not release N2 (not sure, would have to check)

Washing the pieces with water and ethanol in between is just for efficiently replacing all water with acetone. Going through Ethanol is preferrable as intermediate to speed things up (getting all the water out with a direct acetone-wash might be difficult. It is pretty common to go through such intermediate washing procedures to avoid any incompatibility between the solvents that need to be exchanged.

Ok two things: First i think you should have the wood upright so the gas does not have to fight against the grain. At the moment the "gas" goes up against wood then goes sideways out of it. After all the grain is like a line of thin tubes next to each other and you basically are laying them down flat instead of standing them up.

For example with a reheated lasagna you would put aluminum ontop to prevent the cheese from burning. Just a thought; I believe this experiment could be more successful if you changed some variables.

1. The direction the pores travel through the wood. You currently have them running in X/Y axis. I believe if you got a cut that had the pores traveling through the Z axis would 1. 2. I would use even less of the activator chemical allowing the thinner liquid to penetrate better especially because it already thickens up during the vacuum process.

There are several things that I noticed that caused issues with your end product.

1. To mitigate bubbles you should have used a resonator and a slight vacumm to extract the bubbles out of your final piece.

2. You could have used a small vice that would have applied the same pressure to both sides as you baked it in your oven.
3. You should have the used multiple grades of sandpaper up to 12,000 to make your wood shine like glass. As a dicotyledons & conifers artist I routinely polish wood like mesquite from 100 to 12k. A few ideas of how to improve your process:

1: sand the wood to a high polish before starting the bleaching and lignin removal processes. This might make things better or worse, no clue, but it's an idea. You could also try doing the sanding after.

2: make a dam around the wood on the glass. You'll need to use something pretty compressible so it doesn't make the wood seperate from the glass as it shrinks. This should help prevent the resin from spreading out of the wood. Maybe you could also try flipping it part way through baking to counteract the gravity thing.

And a point about why your first attempt had so many broken and cracked pieces. Last time, you used endgrain, which is a bunch of short wood fibers running through the thickness of the wood, held together by lignin. Thin slices of endgrain are already very weak, and you removed the binder that holds the fibers together. This time you had the grain running along the length of the piece. Removing the lignin should weaken in slightly, but what you are making is essentially fiber-reinforced plastic, where the fibers are all wood fibers running the length of the part, which makes it quite strong.

检验实木片是否达到所需的透明度，可以直接将处理过的木片放在水里完全浸泡后得到初步的效果，而不必每次用树脂进行试样。木片第一次放进树脂里必须抽真空，将里面的空气完全抽干净后，反复几次抽真空-泄压-抽真空-泄压，直至没有气泡为止。木片第一次浸泡树脂后有气泡，再想补救而进行第二次抽真空+浸泡树脂，已经是作用不大了，因为第一次浸泡树脂时，树脂已经将大部分纤维或者导孔封闭了，大量的气泡已经封闭在里面了，进行第二次浸泡树脂时，树脂已经很难再进入木片内了，不过木片周边的纤维空隙或者导孔空隙还是可以填充的。树脂应该选择12小时固化以有足够的施工时间，而太快固化的树脂会在表面造成应力集中，从表面看到彩虹线条可以得到证实，板材两面应力不均，会令板材弯曲变形。希望看得明中文，祝好运。

the thickness needs to be less than the final thickness, but enough to retain the MMA as it spreads out.

I think it'd work better on the thicker pieces if you put the bleaching/lignin removing process in a vacuum so it could penetrate in further. As someone trained in autobody work, let me tell you you used WAY too much compound when polishing those. A dime sized drop would've been more than enough and doing polishing you should get a mechanical buffer/polisher with a foam pad or a jeweler's wheel cotton pad on a bench grinder. Don't even put pressure on it, just let the machine do the work and keep it fast. You'll be amazed how much better it'll turn out. Honestly a headlight restoring kit would likely work just fine for that.

Next time offset the pieces for easier removal and try thin plastic or a flexable material inbetween the glass. Maybe oil, laqure or latex paint, then sand it off. Your wood could also not be smooth enough. Like how metal is only reflective at 8000 grit or higher and dull at 300 grit.

Hey, next time you attempt this , and I know it will be a long while. I have a few suggestion for you.
1. When you are removing the Lignum(sp) try to not rush the initial steps with the larger pieces.
2. See if you can make your solution a little less viscous (about 20% less if feasible,) this will allow it to flow better into the pores of the wood
3. With the less viscous material, run the vacuum longer, about 75% longer than your largest piece on this run. For each of the runs.
4. After you are done with the vacuum cycles, find a way, without exposing it to atmosphere, to put it under about 2.758 bar of pressure for 3 times to total length of time it was under vacuum. This to to force the rest of the material into areas that vacuum was unable to do.

Then bake as normal.

Ok, 105C for 25hrs for 1/8 inch balsa is way  overkill even if it were green. A half hour for the kiln dried stuff you had would be sufficient unless it was stored outside in very humid conditions. As someone that spent a year with tables and charts and weighing multiple samples to see how different woods reacted to humidity...typicially anything less than a half inch can be dried to 10% moisture in about an hour. Wood is very hydroscopic and but with also wick moisture away along the grain to reach an equalibrium fairly quickly as well depending on the integrity of the grain and density.

Hey nile. I had some thoughts on how the process might be improved, especially around the vacuum pulling and the resin injection. I've got some experience with resins/epoxy and whatnot, so it might help 🤷‍♂️

Firstly, the vaccums you were pulling were to remove the acetone, as well as inject the resin. Ideally you want to do this in two steps. The first vaccums you pull should be left on for some time to allow the acetone to completely evaporate and liberate it from all liquids - you're essentially freeze drying it. Run a few pulls of a vacuum and allow the piece to completely dry, then try the second steps...

Secondly, the second runs of vacuum pulls to inject the resin don't need to be 15 minute pulls. All you're doing at this stage is pulling out the air, and letting the resin fill all the gaps that the air was in. So pull a vacuum until the piece stops bubbling, then release the air. Do this a few times until you see no more bubbles coming from the piece; but remember that the time under vacuum is basically doing nothing except thickening the resin. This is essentially the reverse of a pressure vessel, which would also force the resin in where the air is squashed - this is a process you can do on epoxy pieces where the bubbles won't shatter the piece. You're doing the opposite, so to achieve a negative pressure inside the wood, you need to pull the vacuum whilst it's under the resin, and then release it. Which brings me onto the last part.

The resin ideally needs to be as thin as possible, so it can bleed into all the gaps more easily when you've pulled out the air and allowed it to suck in the resin in it's place. Maybe once you've seen the initiator do it's job (i.e. it stops releasing it's gassy friends) get the piece submerged in it and pull the short vacuums. That will allow it to fill easier.

Lastly, I'm no expert on this, but maybe using some sealant / silicon gel around the piece to hold the resin in place, and not flow away, might help with keeping the top nice and flat. Obviously, it needs to be runny enough to be squished between the glass sandwich, but might help.

I wonder if your problems with methylmethacrylate polymerization were caused by the MEHQ (methyl hydroquinone or 4-methoxyphenol) inhibitor (30 ppm according to your bottle's label).  This relies on oxygen from the air to scavenge free radicals and prevent polymerization.  Usually MEHQ is removed (by passing the inhibited monomer through a column of activated alumina) or inactivated (by removing air under vacuum or with nitrogen sparging) before polymerization.  If this is not done, then polymerizations become dependent on solution oxygen concentration which is effected by things like stir rate, temperature, container geometry, etc.  Did the original paper say anything about how they treated their methylmethacrylate monomer?
If you revisit this one day in the future, I would suggest making some molds to prevent the acrylic just spreading on the glass surface and maybe prevent the top looking so rough.

By the looks of teh wood grain and the cloudiness in the end product, there may still be some air trapped within the fibres of the wood. a solution could be to soak the wood in the Sodium Chlorite solution for longer, to eat out more of the Lignin, and to access that trapped air. after the solvent washes, another method could be to pull a slight vaccum while in an acetone bath in order to replace that air with acetone before the MMA gets involved, or, as the unpolymerised MMA has a slightly higher vapour pressure than Acetone, you could pull a slight vaccum with MMA to remove the air and acetone and replace with unpolymerised MMA, then introduce partially polymerised MMA and allow it to polymerise the remaining MMA at and increased temp and pressure to reduce vapour loss at that point and for an extended period of time. this should finish the polymerisation without allowing any vapour pockets or any unreacted MMA to remain. it will take far longer to acheive however in theory (and i have absolutely no means of testing this) should result in a clearer product. and finally post proccessing will still be required with the sanding and polishing steps to acheive a final result.

That your polymerization didn't work as expected might be due to the inhibitor that is added to the MMA. A destillation should fix that (or just adding more initiators as you did). Radical polymerizations are also highly dependent on conditions like stirring rate, air humidity and room temperature in an open setup like yours. Using different stirring bars, stirring rates or even filling the flask more than before influences your kinetics quite a bit. Also you usually want to work oxygen and water free if you do radical polymerizations as they can terminate the chain growth process as well. Nice job on the wood! Makes me want to try it, too.

i have a couple of suggestions. first off, there are products used to stabilize wood, these products are made from MMA. these products are called cactus juice and gator venom and they are meant to work under vacuum. from what i can tell (of course i know not everything makes the final cut) you need to go MUCH longer on the bleaching process, like maybe triple it or something (if it wont damage the wood to go extra long, then just forget about it for a day, or even put it in fresh bleach after the first 7 hours). but more importantly, you need to just run the vacuum continuously until you no longer see bubbles. there are plenty of youtube videos on how to use the cactus juice. from what I understand you need to keep the wood submerged in the MMA with a weight and once the bubbling stops, remove vacuum and leave the part submerged for at least as long as it was under vacuum. i have used these products before on some projects i have done in the past, and the process took days to pull out the bubbles and days more under atmospheric conditions, not minutes (admittedly that was for 13-25mm thick and much denser wood).

as a side note you might try baking the wood to remove all liquids right before treatment with the MMA to see if there is a notable difference between baking and not baking the wood.

I wonder if it could be done with cactus juice. Cactus juice is a resin that some wood workers use in a process called Resin Impregnated wood or Wood Stabilization. They put the wood in a vacuum chamber with cactus juice and suck out as much air as they safely could, and the juice fills up the space. They then take the wood and put it in an oven and turn it on a low heat. The wood becomes extremely durable and it takes effort to dent it.

But about the reason the bottom side kept coming out better might actually be something extremely simple... even the best of ovens don't heat 100% evenly, especially when one side of the glass is sitting on a wood "floor" and the other just has tungsten on it, those two disperse heat differently, so it gave you a different result on each side. Maybe if you just put a little stand for the glass so it's "floating" in the oven, it'll give you a more consistent result since it'll be air touching the glass panels and not wood/tungsten and as for keeping the glass panels together you could just bolt their corners together (with clamps or something like a vice even).

Your hands are not flat so if you're trying to hand sand something to make it flat you will fail. What you need to do is glue sand paper onto the glass and use a easily removable glue to glue the "clear" glass to the other piece of glass. Then you just sandwich the two pieces of glass together and you rotate the glass with the wood attached too it around to produce a sanding motion. This will cause the wood to be sanded as perfectly flat as you can get it without machines. Then just continue up the grits on the sandpaper until you get your desired polish. Then flip the wood and do the other side.

here I have another idea along these lines, what if you used sawdust instead of whole wood? benefits would be near complete lignin removal and easier to vacuum down.

Also if you do try to do a whole window I think I might have a few things you might want to consider due to how the lignin is removed there are channels left in the wood, this is why when you vacuum down the piece, the time to vacuum it down properly grows with the area or more specifically the length of the grain,

so why not make the grain shorter artificially there are 2 ways I could see of doing this:

one would be to score the wood before removing the lignin, this would have 2 benefits, one would be making the removal of the lignin faster, and removing the air bubbles faster the issue is this would create other issues like having visible score lines in the wood.


the other way would be to make the window on pieces and to join them later with the plastic, much like making wood flooring this way you can cut the wood across the grain and have a shorter run of space left by the lignin.

There is another option and it would work similarly to your vacuum filter that you use, where you would make a small tank looking jig that would have a very tight seal against the wood and it would just pull the plastic through using vacuum. The issue is this would still take a long time to remove the lignin, and in order to get a proper seal you might have to have some sacrificial stock to make a seal out of resin or plastic, and it would likely be better to have the vast majority of the lignin removed wood submerged in resin rather than having it hanging in vacuum because this will have the effect of pulling the resin trough with vacuum rather than pushing the resin through with atmospheric pressure. so you will have fewer defects.

also as you make larger and larger pieces you will need higher and higher weight, there will get to a point where no matter what glass you choose you will cause the glass to shatter so this begs the question: why do the plates have to even be glass, what if you used a large polished metal plate, a few benefits to this is you can use a simple screw press to apply the weight rather than stacking things on top and instead of having to have the whole press in the oven you could use bolts to secure the plates while the assembly is in the press, for a window size to provide the proper amount of tensile strength you will likely need to weld supporting material to the plates and use many bolts.

Some of your problems may have come from the rough texture of the wood before bleaching. Maybe try to sand the surface prior to treatment.

Also, the MMA around the wood on the glass is probably curing before the MMA in the wood. As such the cured surrounding plexiglass is now holding the glass up off the surface of the wood and preventing the weight from pressing down. I would suggest to remove as much MMA from around the wood prior to curing in the oven.

Would be interesting to see measurements of the thickness of the cured material on the wood verses the surrounding excess material.

Best luck on future trials.

I remember watching the original video on this project when it came out, and I've thought about it regularly ever since. I'm only halfway through the video, but I'm gonna suggest the same thing I did in 2018;

instead of placing the wood into the vacuum chamber, use it as the "lid", with the MMA on top and vacuum chamber below. This way, when you pull the vacuum, the atmospheric pressure on the MMA should force it into the tiny "channels" (I believe you referred to them as tubes in the original video--though it may be different because of the different type of wood) between the fibres. The benefit, hopefully, will be that since you don't have competing forces pushing the MMA into the wood from all sides, it will be able to penetrate all the way through. Additionally, you'll know when the empty spaces have been filled because at that point the MMA should start dripping into the vacuum chamber after passing all the way through the wood.

Obviously you'll need to line up the grain of the wood to allow the MMA to pass through, which may be much more difficult (or impossible) with balsa, but it might be worth investigating if you ever decide to revisit the project in search of a new method.

Honestly i think the problem you are having with the setteling is because you need to turn the piece about 1/4 of the way through the final baking process so that it will settle in the the center of the plastic. the other option would be to have the piece sit horizontal instead of vertical on a stand and use long surface C-clamps instead of an actual weight ( i would also recommend using a force gauge on them before the cook and making on the clamp where you want them to stop so that the force is evenly applied).  this is coming from a plastics hobbyist and ive had a good deal of success with this method for curing silicones and pvc i dont see why it wouldnt apply to your particular plastic.

If you want to have a go at this again I have 3 things that I think would improve the process:
1. Use regular wood. I think the Balsa has too many or too big pores.
2. Ditch the weight. It makes the top surface heat up slower so the resin has the chance to pull away from the glass exposing the wood fibers. Without it you might not need to put it in resin a second time.
3. Don't ditch the aluminum foil. I think it helps to spread the heat evenly.

Hey, @NileRed  I love your videos so much.
I commented on your last community post but that was about a week ago, but my hopes are that you will see this.

A while ago I found out that Xenon can form compounds. (xenon hexifloroplatinate) This was really surprising to me and I wanted to share with you, I could not find any preparation for this compound and some of the chemicals are quite expensive. However you can find them all online, most expensive Part is going to be the Platinum. However xenon is also pretty expensive.

Here is the reaction:

Xe + 2(O₂ + )[PtF₆]→(XeII)[PtF₆]₂ + 2O₂

From what I know is the preparation involves cooling everything down to 77 Kelvin° and slowly bringing it back up to temperature.
The compound is called xenon hexifloroplatinate.
